Detailed Description

Author:
Kek <http://cuddle-clan.org>

Piemod provides a Python engine to Cube 2: Sauerbraten servers.

Certain module functions will be executed upon determined server events. Those events are listed in the "Function Documentation" section.

Links

Code repository, documentation and bug tracking system: https://github.com/tukkek/piemod

Chat: piemod at irc.gamesurge.net or https://gamesurge.net/chat/piemod

Python event handlers

Functions that can be defined as entry-points to the modules are named here as "event_foo". In Python you should name them as "foo" only.

Handlers take only one variable: a dictionary, whose keys are the parameter names in italic here.

Server module

Importing the provided 'server' in a module enables you to communicate back with the server. The function listed here as 'server_bar' can then be found in Python as 'server.bar'.

Example (welcome.py)

 import server

 welcome = 'Hello world!'

 def connect(args):
  server.msg(args['cn'],welcome)
  server.cs('quit')

Types

This document shows C parameter types. It's easy to assume from those which Python types they will convert to:

CPython
boolbool
intint
char*str

Configuration

Add the line below to server-init.cfg, where [path] is the directory Python modules should be loaded from.

 alias piemodfolder [path]

License

ZLIB. It can be found in src/readme_source.txt.

As required, all modified files should carry a header notice. Piemod covers only source files, no media is included.

Development philosophy

Python > C

Always prefer Python modules to changing C. Python is easier and faster to write, debug and maintain.

CubeScript > Piemod

Always prefer adding CubeScript support to creating new Python<->C stuff.

Doxygen > *

Always update the documentation before the code and revise it after coding. Fail to do so and you might be liable to users requesting your sepukku.

Generated files

piemod.diff

Git diff from previous release.

modules/README.txt

Brief description of the example Python modules.

Help wanted!

Piemod is looking for commit contributors who can extend the source code and respect the project's philosophy. New or modified Python modules are also welcome, as we aim to offer more features in the default package.

You can also help by opening issues on the bug tracking system for feature requests or bug reports.

Dependencies

To run piemod you will need a Python 3 runtime in your system.

What you will need to compile:

  • Python 3.3m development libraries
  • Doxygen (not needed if you remove the single Doxygen line from the makefile)
  • Cube 2: Sauerbraten dependencies.

Function Documentation

void event_gameintermission (  ) 

Called when a game ends and the scoreboard is shown.

bool event_gameover (  ) 

Called a certain delay after event_gameintermission() .

Returns:
If you return False then a new map is not going to be automatically loaded. This can be done for manual control over map and mode rotation.
void event_gamestart (  ) 

Called at the beggining of a match.

void event_playerconnect ( int  cn  ) 

New client connected. Adding bots will not raise an event.

Parameters:
cn The client number of the connecting client.
void event_playerdeath ( int  fragger,
int  fragged 
)

Called when a player is killed.

Parameters:
fragger Actor's client number.
fragged Target's client number.
void event_playerdisconnect ( int  cn  ) 

A player has left the game.

Parameters:
cn Client number of the player.
void event_playerspectate ( int  cn,
bool  spectator 
)

A player has moved from or to spectator.

Parameters:
cn Client number of the player.
spectator True if client is now spectating, False if he is no longer spectating.
void event_playerswitchteam ( int  cn  ) 

A player has switched team.

Parameters:
cn Client number of the player.
bool event_playertext ( int  cn,
string  text,
bool  team 
)

Chat message was sent.

Parameters:
cn Number of the client who sent the message.
text Text sent.
team False if the message was public, True if only for the author's team.
Returns:
If you return False the message will be blocked and not sent to other players.
int server_cs ( const char *  cubescript  ) 

Executes CubeScript. The avaiable functions are easy to read in piemodcs.cpp, all should work as expected in client-side cubescript.

Parameters:
cubescript CubeScript to be executed.
Returns:
Result from the code execution.
PyObject* server_match (  ) 

Get match information.

Returns:
Dictionary with the following keys:
KeyTypeDescription
mapstrName of the map currently being played
modeintCurrent game mode (-1=demo playback, 0=ffa, 1=coop edit, 2=teamplay, 3=instagib, 4=instagib team, 5=efficiency, 6=efficiency team, 7=tactics mode, 8=tactics team mode, 9=capture mode, 10=regen capture, 11=ctf, 12=insta, 13=protect, 14=insta protect, 15=hold mode,16=insta hold, 17=efficiency ctf, 18=efficiency protect, 19=efficiency hold, 20=collect, 21=insta collect, 22=efficiency collect)
void server_msg ( int  cn,
char *  text 
)

Send message to a player.

Parameters:
cn Number of the destination client for the message.
text Message to be sent.
PyObject* server_players (  ) 

Get all players' information.

Returns:
Dictionary of all players by client number. Each player is a dictionary with the following keys:
KeyTypeDescription
namestrNickname
privilegeintPrivilege level (none=0, master=1, auth=2, admin=3)
statusint Player status (alive=0, dead=1, spawning=2, lagged=3, editing=4, spectator=5)
teamstrPlayer's current team
